DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNITY NEWS : FAIRFAX ; D-DAY REALITY COMES ALIVE FOR ROTC CADET
DOC.TEXT: To 17-year-old Charles Butler , generations removed from World_War_II , D-day was something that lived only on a page in a history book . But after touring England earlier this month and taking_part in events commemorating the 50th anniversary of D-day , Butler says the massive military offensive mounted by Allied forces on June 6 , 1944 , lives in him now . " A lot of people lost their family and friends , " said Butler , a Southwest Los Angeles resident and Hamilton High student . " They stood around me crying . . . . It ' s very real for them -- like it happened yesterday. " Butler was one of 24 ROTC naval cadets from the American Southwest chosen by ROTC officials to make the two-week trip earlier this month . The group traveled_to several English ports from which the invasion of France was launched , saw President Clinton and French President Francois Mitterand at D-day events and heard testimonies -- many of them eyewitness accounts of the battle that turned the tide of the war in Europe . One veteran told Butler he parachuted into the wrong spot , about 20 miles north of the appointed place on the Normandy beach in France . And while the cadets performed military_drills for such royalty as the Queen_Mother and Prince Philip , they were getting the red-carpet treatment from the_British . Said Butler , the only African American in his group : " They saw us as diplomatic guests , even though we ' re young . It was kind of a shock to come_back here and be treated like a kid again. " Butler and the cadets stayed_on the Bristol , a British destroyer , and toured Southampton and London . But Butler said the most enduring experience will be honoring D-day . " If it wasn ' t for D-day , " he said , " the Germans might have won the war . And the world would be a very different place today. " ERIN J . AUBRY
